author: E-mail: thehunt@nytimes.com
body: A VICTORIAN mansion -- that's the kind of home Cynthia von Buhler was holding out for. Was it possible? It was certainly worth a try. Ms. von Buhler would stay up late, scrutinizing online listings for grand historic homes, and searching the Craigslist Web site for words like ''mansion.'' ''Believe it or not, there are some,'' she said. A Victorian
title: THE HUNT; Looking For a House And a Turret

body: A 26-year old Brooklyn man who the authorities said had abused his wife in the past was stabbed to death inside her apartment early yesterday by her 19-year-old sister, the police said. The stabbing followed a violent argument in which the man hit his wife's mother, according to the police. The man, Carl Upsher, and his wife, Paterish Moore, 27 had
title: Man Killed in Family Fight By Wife's Sister, Police Say

body: The four candidates in the city's Democratic mayoral primary tomorrow have been campaigning for months, but for many voters, the race could just as well have begun last week. Dozens of interviews throughout the city suggest that it is only in the past few days that voters have focused on the campaign. The race had no emotional issues to generate
title: As Primary Draws Near, Decisions Start To Take Shape

body: Babies were born, and then they walked, and a contentious presidential race came and went. There were two heat waves, a blackout and 665 Yankees and Mets home games. Scores of fresh New Yorkers, from Calcutta and Kalamazoo, whose memories of the 2001 attack on the city were formed by the television screen, have rolled up to the gates of the
title: With a Wrench of the Gut; A Sight or a Sound Can Bring 9/11 Flooding Back

title: DIRECTIONS; Coming Soon to Brooklyn: Alabama

body: GRACE ADAMS and her family have seen the worst days of 870 Riverside Drive. They moved in after the landlord absconded in the mid-1970's, leaving the city to foreclose on the building for unpaid taxes. They endured corrupt managers and broken pipes. They stuck around when rape suspects were arrested nearby, and when the police shot a gun-wielding
title: Once Derelict, Now Desirable

body: A Brooklyn man died Friday night after he was stabbed in the neck, and on Staten Island a man standing in front of a deli was killed early yesterday after he was shot by a man in a moving car, the police said. No one was arrested yesterday afternoon in either killing, and the motives had not been determined, the police said. They said that around
title: 2 Killed in Attacks in Brooklyn and on S.I.

body: Williamsburg Village Style Freddy Jakubowski has tended bar at the Greenpoint Tavern on Bedford Avenue since 1985. It was 1992 when a place arrived unlike any other there, a little restaurant called the L Cafe. "Some girl opened it," Mr. Jakubowski said. "She was a good girl. I'm not much of an architect or a decorator, but she did it something
title: THE NEW BROOKLYNS/TIPPING POINTS; The Day When Back in the Day Ended

body: The new face of New York City is taking shape among the graceful Victorian houses and stout apartment buildings of Ditmas Park, Brooklyn. This softly shaded patch of Flatbush is one of the city's most polyglot and polychrome, what city demographers like to call a melting-pot neighborhood, because no one ethnic or racial group is dominant and many
title: Brooklyn's Technicolor Dream Quilt

body: WHAT do you get when you sell a three-bedroom, 1,500-square-foot Brooklyn Heights co-op for $1 million and buy a seven-bedroom, 4,000-square-foot house 10 minutes away in Prospect Park South for $1.025 million? title: LIVING IN/Prospect Park South, Brooklyn; Near Prospect Park, a Touch of Greenwich

body: ''LOOK!'' my friend yelped, as if she had spotted a species that had long since gone extinct. ''Driveways!'' We were in a sliver of Ditmas Park, Brooklyn, that seemed plucked from another planet or at least from a city more Rockwellian than ours. With every quirkily painted Victorian house and porch swing we passed, the name of the restaurant we
title: $25 AND UNDER; American Fare in Apple-Pie Surroundings

body: WITH two young children, Robin Hardman and Peter Hill loved living in Stuyvesant Town -- the playground right outside, the playmates across the hall, the 10-minute walk to school (15 if the kids dilly-dallied). But inside, the living conditions were tight. Leo, now 9, and Mae, 6, shared the bedroom. Their parents slept on a pullout sofa bed in the
title: THE HUNT; One Family Makes a Move, And Four Others Follow
